html:
8.18.17  8:34 pm   does the main progression 'shape of you' by ed sheeran go i VI iv VII or i iv VI VII? both orders sound like the original song to me.

     they are both extremely similar, 4min and b6maj are sister chords. but they did it as 1, 4min, b6, b7. in this case, wherever you hit the 4min (as opposed to the b6) will feel a bit more 'pensive' where as the b6 will feel a bit more 'power' that's the only way i can really describe the difference

8.18.17  8:42 am   i definitely was born in wrong time. if everything has been fucking done, what am i gonna do? possibilities are infinite and of course there is still so much to invent or prevent or discover or "be" and future is impatient but fiction is a universe, actually countless universes because imagination has no limits. i feel like -this block makes me feel like, everything can be imagined is already imagined and even if i know it's not true, i just can't find that perfect and original idea i'm looking for. i watch my thoughts running and disappearing in my head, when i am able to catch them, i see something else: a book, a movie, a show, a lyrics, somebody's words... an idea similar to anything else doesn't satisfy me, the thing i'm gonna do must be different. it has to be the best. in this situation, what the fuck am i gonna write about?

     i think you need to just start writing more. 'good' vs 'new' can be a delicate balance, and they can be at odds with each other because if you try to go for 'good' it may have already been done, and if you try to go for 'new' it might be off the map but not necessarily 'good.' the only way to get practice here is to just start doing a lot of both without any fear of being too far one way or the other

8.18.17  7:33 am   pls make website easier to use and more pretty

     i made it exactly the way i like it, and i continue to be excited daily about the way that i made it. what may be exciting for you would be to leave

     no

      If it is, then warm/hot must mean higher than a specific temperature, but what would it be? Im confused.

     warm/hot means at a higher temperature than another thing

8.18.17  12:18 am   thanks for the help earlier! i'm the one learning the peter gabriel song Here Comes the Flood. (i'm not asking about theory btw hahahaha, please don't move to space, we like having you here.) what i'm trying to learn is the full, accurate piano part in the original key, from the Shaking The Tree version. i don't think i communicated my questions very well though, or at all, so i'll try again.

i have experience in percussion, but also some guitar and mandolin, learning with tabs and by ear - i'm the one that thinks strings sound soapy. but i can JUST BARELY read music at all. i am teaching myself piano, and how to read music. right now my ears are ahead of my fingers and feet, which are all MILES ahead of what i can actually read. there's a lot of "music language" that i've been exposed to but don't really understand yet. i want to learn this stuff so i can play and communicate with others better, and to be able to write down things i make up.

my strategy is: A) have fun learning songs that i like as accurately as i can, by ear. B) learn to read using beginner music books and get frustrated because i can only read things like hot cross buns so far. (maybe a tad more advanced than that.) it was fairly equal a month ago but now i spend 95% of the time i play on A and 5% on B. so, i haven't progressed on reading much. that's problem 1.

problem 2 is: i think i have a pretty good ear. BUT i sometimes hit a limit: when it gets to be 5 or 6 or more keys pressed at the same time, it all starts to sound like One Big Thing and i have trouble distinguishing the notes, especially low ones. (keep in mind that i can't NAME the notes/chords from hearing them, i can just copy what i hear after hunting around a bit.) i know some musicians are able to identify notes in big chords really easily and accurately, and it seems almost like they were just born with that ability, which is kind of scary,

     i think if you keep using a pause and hunt strategy, (make sure you are using a local copy of the file, not streaming. if it's streaming like on youtube or something you're never gonna be able to unpause-pause as quickly as you need to) if you keep using the pause and hunt strategy for more and more songs, you will learn more and more and there will be less and less things that confuse you, and less and less things that fall outside your familiar classification system. if there are any chords or notes you are wondering about, i will be able to tell you if you show me where you heard it

     because maybe tha t means that i was born with the abilities i have and can't upgrade them. so my questions are:

1) will my ears develop the more i use them?

     yes

     
2) is learning music going to be a bit frustrating no matter what, given my situation, or could i be doing something better? or just have a better attitude lol. do you have any advice????

     it sounds like the right thing for you to do, and it sounds like you are doing great

     
thanks, x

8.17.17  7:19 pm   Do you like music theory?

     the term 'music theory' seems to not have any meaning to me other than make me want to sell my belongings and move to space every time i inevitably hear it in a question on this page. i have wanted to say this for a long time, but the problem is any time i make a statement like this, inevitably the next question will be someone asking "why" and i'm just so tired of this issue i think i am going to put myself into a coma. i apologize for the inconvenience. if you want further clarification i'm sure you can find it in hundreds of other questions throughout this questions section
